Wherefore (√¥ my ≈øonnes) be yee wi≈øe as ≈øerpents, innocent as doues, & fight manfully again≈øt the old ≈øerpent. O loue one another, I haue receiued this not of man, but of my Sauiour, who ≈øaith,
This is my commandement, that yee loue one another. As out of one root many branches do ≈øpring, ≈øo out of charitie ≈øpring all vertues. If I ≈øpeake with the tongues of men, and angels, and haue not loue, I am nothing, ≈øaith the Apo≈øtle. He that hath loue is benigne, and patient. He hath true loue, which doth not only loue the neare≈øt vnto him by kindred, and in the fle≈øh, as the heathen doe, but which loueth his enemy, euen as his friend. By this one thing a man may know, that he abideth in loue, if he loueth him that is again≈øt him. There are very many that loue, but
they loue ami≈ø≈øe, for in louing man they oftentimes loo≈øe the loue of God. They which loue any thing more than God are not worthy of God. In all vertues temperance is required, vertue mu≈øt alwaies keepe a meane. To loue too much, or too litle is euill. All loue, that hurteth, is to be anoyded. Through too much loue ≈øome haue fallen into fil thine≈ø≈øe, through too litle ≈øome haue fallen into enuie. Ouer-much loue would alwaies ≈øee the thing, which it loueth. This loue is ignorant of iu≈øtice, and truth it wants rea≈øon, it knowes no mea≈øure, neither can it thinke
any thing, but that, which it loueth. It is impo≈ø≈øible, that a man, which hath ≈øuch loue, ≈øhould offer acceptable prayers vnto God, or plea≈øe God. This loue is not charitie, but folly. We ought to loue all our brethren, as our ≈øelues, but yet ≈øo, as that we loue not their vices. It is loue to puni≈øh ≈øinne, it is iu≈øt to loue more the better man. Men are ≈øo to be loued, that goodne≈ø≈øe may be exalted, and vice di≈øgraced. He that is without true loue, is without God, becau≈øe God is loue, and loue is God. He that dwelleth in loue hath already begun to dwell in heauen. Where there is
true loue, there is no enuie, no ambition, no backbiting, no murmuring, or mocking, but one, and the ≈øame will. Therefore I be≈øeech you, whil≈øi yee haue time, that ye receiue not the grace of God in vaine. In this ≈øhort time of our life let vs ≈øow, and ≈øo we ≈øhall reape in due time. The dayes of man are ≈øhort; our life is cut off as a weauers threed, death commeth as a theefe, and euery mans workes follow him. Whil≈øt ye haue light, walke not in darknes, he that walketh in darkne≈ø≈øe knoweth not whither be goeth. Your light is Chri≈øt, which doth ≈øhine in darkne≈ø≈øe; come there
fore vnto him, the liuing ≈øtone, reiected indeede or men, but cho≈øen of God, that yee as liuing ≈øtones may be built vpon him, and yee may carry your ≈øelues in all things, as the mini≈øters of God, in much patience, in tribulations, in nece≈ø≈øities, in ≈øtreights, in ≈øcourges, in pri≈øons, in labours, in fa≈øtings, in cha≈øtitie, in long-≈øuffering, in the Holy Gho≈øt, and in loue vnfained, in the word of truth, and in the virtue of God. Let there not be a lye told among≈øt you, for euery lyer is abominable vnto God. God is truth, and lying is oppo≈øite to truth. Flie euery idle word, for of euery
idle and vaine word, wee mu≈øt giue accompt vnto God. Loue ≈øilence, where there is much talking, there cannot but be much lying. The ≈øpeech bewraieth, what a man is. Let no word come from your mouth, which may not ≈øauour of Chri≈øt, alwaies meditate vpon Gods law. Surely nothing hurts a man more, then euill ≈øociety, for ≈øuch is a man made, as they are, who≈øe ≈øociety hee v≈øeth. The Wolfe neuer dwells with the Lambe. A cha≈øt man flies the ≈øociety of the luxurious. I thinke it impo≈øtible for a man to remaine long in good workes, that v≈øeth euill
≈øociety euery day. With the holy, ≈øaith the P≈øalmi≈øt, thou ≈øhalt be holy, with the innocent, thou ≈øhalt be innecent, & with the froward, thou ≈øhalt learne frowardne≈ø≈øe. For euen as euill company hurteth, ≈øo good companie profiteth, Nothing can be compared to this trea≈øure, hee that hath found good Companions, hath found life, & flowes with riches. And to ≈øpeake truely, very ≈øeldome is a man made either good or euill, but by company. The heart of a child is like vnto a table, wherin nothing is (at the fir≈øt) ingrauen; therefore what hee receiueth from company, he reteineth
euen vnto old age, whether it be good, or bad. Let youth keepe company with men of yeares, and wi≈øedome: for if hee be linked to one like vnto him≈øelfe, by daily fellow≈øhippe, hee ≈øhall fall from folly, to folly. Aboue all things (my ≈øonnes) ≈øweare not, neither by heauen, not by earth, nor by any other Oath. Out of who≈øe mouth, Oathes are heard, in him is little knowledge, and loue of God. If it be not true which I ≈øweare, I doe in effect denie God: for God hath for bidden, to take his name in vaine. Be in≈øtant in continuall prayers. Frequent, and
deuout prayer doth much auaile. Prayer doth lift vp a man from earth to heauen, and makes him to ≈øpeake with God. Hee obteineth grace of God, if his Prayer be deuout, and mixt with teares. At the praiers of Elias, the beauen gaue raine, which had beene ≈øhut vp three yeares, and ≈øix monethes. If ye want any thing, aske it of the Lord by prayer, and weeping, being no whit doubtfull: for who≈øoeuer hath faith, but ≈øo much as
a graine of mu≈øtard ≈øeed, what≈øoeuer he ≈øhall aske, ≈øhall be granted vnto him. The ≈øame Lord, that then was, is now al≈øo rich in all things: wherefore let God now be your hope, your ioy, your thinking, and your de≈øire. For of him, in him, and through him are all things, in whom we liue, and moue, and haue our being, and without whom we are nothing. And now (√¥ my ≈øonnes) I ≈øhall not ≈øpeake many things to you, for the houre is come, vnto which I was borne, vpon this condition I came into the world, that I might goe out againe. The Lord ≈øpared not his owne ≈øon,
but made them to die vpon the Cro≈ø≈øe for vs all, by who≈øe death our death is dead: for none of vs liueth to him≈øelfe, but dieth, whether wee liue, we liue to the Lord, and if we die, we die to the Lord, therfore whether we liue, or die we are the Lords: and for this cau≈øe Chri≈øt is called the Lord of the liuing, and of the dead. For if Chri≈øt bee dead, ≈øurely the ≈øeruant is not about his Ma≈øter, we mu≈øt al≈øo die, and if he be ri≈øen againe, we haue al≈øo mo≈øt ≈øirme hope, that we ≈øhall ri≈øe againe, and if he bee ri≈øen to die no more, neither ≈øhall we die any more after our re≈øurrection, but
≈øhall alway abide with him in glory. When Chri≈øt died, a man like vnto vs died, that the body of ≈øinne might be de≈øtroyed, that we might be made one body together with him. Wherefore (my beloued ≈øonnes) although I now die, I beleeue, that my Redeemer liueth, and that I ≈øhall ri≈øe vp out of the earth, at the la≈øt day, and ≈øhall bee couered againe with this skinne, and in this my fle≈øh I ≈øhall ≈øee him my Sauiour, whom I my ≈øelfe ≈øhall ≈øee, who now ≈øpeake, whom ye ≈øee now dying, and not any other for me. And the≈øe very eies, whereby I now ≈øee you,

Wherefore reioice with me, and ≈øing, ca≈øt away the garments of mourning, and heauine≈ø≈øe, prai≈øe the Lord, ≈øing a P≈øalme vnto his name, giue glorie to his prai≈øe, for hitherto I haue walked through fire, & water, & behold now he refre≈øheth me. I will enter into the hou≈øe of the Lord, that I may pay my vowes from day to day. Oh how great a game it is to me to die? Becau≈øe Chri≈øt ≈øhall bee my life againe: Behold the earthly hou≈øe of this habitation, is di≈ø≈øolued, that another may ≈øucceede not made with hands, eternall in the

Behold I now receiue the prize, for which I ran in the race, I touch the hauen, which I haue de≈øired with ≈øo great a de≈øire. Behold I am carried from darkene≈ø≈øe to light, from dangers to ≈øafetie, from pouertie to riches, from battell to victorie, from heauine≈ø≈øe to ioy, from a temporall life to eternall; and from a filthy ≈øtincke to a mo≈øt ≈øweete ≈ømell. Here I am blinde, there I am inlightened, here I am wounded, there I am
